Seed CSS

A light-weight, mobile first and responsive CSS boilerplate.

Why you're gonna love use Seed CSS?

It's for modern browsers.


Quick start

Get started to your projects with a very small footprint CSS boilerplate like this.


Light-weight

Just 11kb of CSS your app needs to load for a mobile first and responsive design.


Full customizable

All written on Sass, what means you can easily customize it as much as you need.


DOWNLOAD

(This page design is proudly written with Seed CSS)


Get started

Just before get started, please notice that Seed CSS was written with modern browsers in mind. That means it just has support for IE9+ (which actually isn't a real modern browser ... but), Chrome, Firefox and Safari, besides mobile browsers. If you need support older browsers, this boilerplate may not help you, but, just in case, you're free to customize it and create your own CSS rules to make it supports those older browser versions.

The most first thing you need to do to start using Seed CSS is import its CSS file into your pages. In order to get the right files, you can either fork this project on Github, or just download the compressed project files to your computer.

After get the latest version of files, import it to your pages as the example below: 

<head >
  ...
  <link href="seed.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" >
</head>

Once you have the Seed CSS stylesheet embeded to your site or application, have a look on all code examples below to get inspired about what features it offers you and what you can do with it. :)

Examples of code


Container

Containers are used to define an enclosed area with a max-width set to 960px on wide screens.

This's a container.
<div class="container" ></div>

Grid

Grids are commonly used to define "grid" based designs. The grid system is responsive, which means you can define the number of columns according to the screen size and it will adapts its width to best fit your content.

Class Detail Remarks
.grid   Defines the grid container
.row   Defines each row of a grid container
.col   Defines each column of a grid container
.sm-* (1 ~ 12) Defines a column size for small screens. It's used concatenated to .col
.md-* (1 ~ 12) Defines a column size for medium screens. It's used concatenated to .col
.lg-* (1 ~ 12) Defines a column size for large screens. It's used concatenated to .col
.offset-* (1 ~ 12) Creates an offset of columns. It's used concatenated to .col

Examples
.md-6 .lg-3
.md-6 .lg-3
.md-6 .lg-3
.md-6 .lg-3
<!-- This's a grid -->
<div class="grid" >
  <!-- This's a row. You can have as many rows as you need. -->
  <div class="row" >
    <!-- This's a column. You can have up to 12 columns in a row. -->
    <div class="col sm-12 md-6 lg-3" > ... </div>
    <div class="col sm-12 md-6 lg-9" > ... </div>
  </div>
</div>

Check this examples out.

1

8

Offsets are also available. To apply offsets, just add the sufix -offset to your classname.

Check it out how to make a colum spanding 6 with a offset of 3.

This' a column of 6 with offset of 3.
<div class="grid" >
  <div class="row" >
    <div class="col sm-6 offset-3" > ... </div>
  </div>
</div>

Typography

All default HTML tags are supported, including but not limited to the below few examples.

Examples

Header 1

Header 2

Header 3

Header 4

Header 5
Header 6

This is an paragraph.
This is a bold text.
This is an italic text.
This is an underlined text.
This is an anchor text. 

<p > ... </p> 
<b > ... </b> 
<i > ... </i> 
<u > ... </u> 
<a href="." > ... </a> 

<!-- Head lines --> 
<h1 > ... </h1> 
<h2 > ... </h2> 
<h3 > ... </h3> 
<h4 > ... </h4> 
<h5 > ... </h5> 
<h6 > ... </h6>

Buttons

Buttons are a really basic elements on any web page or app, and it comes in a couple of different flavors in Seed CSS. In order to use the primary just add the class name .btn-primary. If you need use anchor (<a />) as button, include the .btn class name on it.

Class Detail Remarks
.btn   Makes anchors looks like buttons
.btn-primary   Defines a 'primary' (blue) colored button
.btn-(*color*)   Defines a colored button. Colors can be: red, orange, green or purple
.btn-(*size*)   Defines a sized button. Sizes can be: small or medium. Default is big
.disabled   Defines disabled buttons. Simply setting the disabled property will also make button looks like disabled
.flat-btn   Defines flat buttons, which means no borders or background colors. You are still able to use .btn-(*color*) and or .btn(*size*) on this button type

Examples
Default
Anchor
Primary (.btn-primary)
Anchor
Colored (.btn-*color*)
Anchor
Anchor
Anchor
Anchor
Disabled (.disabled)
Anchor
Flat (.flat-btn)
Anchor
Medium (.btn-medium)
Anchor
Small (.btn-small)
Anchor 
<!-- .btn class makes an anchor looks like a button --> 
<a class="btn" href="..." > ... </a> 

<!-- default buttons and input[type="button"] -->
<button type="button" > ... </button> 
<input type="button" value="..." />

<!-- .btn-primary makes buttons colored -->
<a class="btn btn-primary" href="..." > ... </a> 
<a class="btn btn-red" href="..." > ... </a> 
<a class="btn btn-green" href="..." > ... </a> 

<!-- .btn-primary makes buttons on different sizes -->
<a class="btn btn-medium" href="..." > ... </a> 
<a class="btn btn-small" href="..." > ... </a> 

<!-- .btn-primary makes disabled buttons -->
<a class="btn disabled" href="..." > ... </a> 
<button disabled > ... </button>

Forms

Probably all websites and apps will contain (at least) one form, so, that's why Seed CSS has a really simple, easy to use and customizable form field stylesheet. Have a look on the examples below:


Examples
<!-- Example of an input text --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <label for="..." > ... </label>
  <input type="text" name="..." >
</div>    
     
<!-- Example of an input password --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <label for="..." > ... </label>
  <input type="password" name="..." >
</div>         
     
<!-- Example of an input email --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <label for="..." > ... </label>
  <input type="email" name="..." placehoder="..." >
</div>         
     
<!-- Example of a dropdown --> 
<div class="field seed-select" > 
  <label for="..." > ... </label>
  <select name="..." >
    <option value="..." > ... </option>
    <option value="..." > ... </option>
    <option value="..." > ... </option>
  </select>
</div>       

<!-- Example of an input radio --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <input type="radio" name="..." >
  <label for="..." >
    ...
  </label>
</div>     

<!-- Example of a checkbox --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <input type="checkbox" name="..." >
  <label for="..." > 
    ... 
  </label>
</div>           
     
<!-- Example of a textarea --> 
<div class="field" > 
  <label for="..." > ... </label>
  <textarea name="..." > ... </textarea>
</div>

Lists

You can make your lists using DL, UL or OL. No special classes are necessary. The style will be applied to the natural element.

Examples

Ordered

  1. First item
  2. Second item
    1. Nested first
    2. Nested second ...
  3. Third item

Unordered

  • First item
  • Second item
    • Nested first
    • Nested second ...
  • Third item
<!-- replace OL by UL or DL for different list types --> 
<ol > 
  <li > ... </li>
  <li > ... </li>
  <li > ... </li>
</ol>

Tables

Tables are supposed to be used for display data.

In that matter, Seed CSS has very special classes to allow you show your data in a very clean and readable way. Basically, just using a default markup for data you'll get a styled table, but, you also can make use of special classes to make your tables even more readable.


Examples

default

Name Email Phone
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900 
<table class="" > 
  <tbody >
    <tr >
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

stripped

Name Email Phone
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900 
<table class="stripped" > 
  <tbody >
    <tr >
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

hovered

Name Email Phone
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900 
<table class="hovered" > 
  <tbody >
    <tr >
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

bordered

Name Email Phone
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900
John Wayne john@wayne.com 123-4567-8900 
<table class="bordered" > 
  <tbody >
    <tr >
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
      <td > ... </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

Media queries

Media queries allows you to make an even more accurated design.

Query Remarks
@media only screen and (min-width: 0px) {} Mobile first queries
@media only screen and (min-width: 320px) {} Larger than mobile
@media only screen and (min-width: 550px) {} Larger than tablet
@media only screen and (min-width: 960px) {} Larger than desktop/laptop pc 
// Mobile first queries 
@media only screen and (min-width: 0px) {
  ...
}

// Larger than mobile
@media only screen and (min-width: 320px) {
  ...
}

// Larger than tablet 
@media only screen and (min-width: 550px) {
  ...
}

// Larger than desktop/laptop pc
@media only screen and (min-width: 960px) {
  ...
}

Utilities

Utilities are classes that can help you to easily show up your data or content in a beatiful way.
It can be used combined with other available classes.


Text alignment
Class Remarks
.align-left Aligns on left
.align-right Aligns on right
.align-center Aligns on center
.align-justify Aligns justified

This is left aligned

<p class="align-left" > ... </p>

This is center aligned 

<p class="align-center" > ... </p>

This is right aligned 

<p class="align-right" > ... </p>

This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. This is justified. 

<p class="align-justify" > ... </p>

Text transform
Class Remarks
.nowrap Forces the HTML to ignore white spaces when wrapping lines.
.camel-case Capitalize the first character of any word
.uc-first Capitalize the first character only from the first word
.upper-case Capitalize all character
.lower-case Make all letters in lower case

This text should not break when the screen width is smaller then the text length. 

<p class="nowrap" > ... </p>

this text should be camel case. 

<p class="camel-case" > ... </p>

only the first character of this text should be capitalized. 

<p class="uc-first" > ... </p>

All letters of this text should be capitalized. 

<p class="upper-case" > ... </p>

All letters of this text should be lower case. 

<p class="lower-case" > ... </p>

Hiding
Class Remarks
.hide Hide an element in any device.
.hide-only-small Hide an element only on small devices only.
.hide-on-medium-and-down Hide an element on all devices, except for large ones
.hide-on-medium-and-up Hide an element on all devices, except for small ones 
<!-- Hide on all devices --> 
<div class="hide" > ... </div>

<!-- Hide on small devices --> 
<div class="hide-only-small" > ... </div>

<!-- Hide on medium and small devices --> 
<div class="hide-on-medium-and-down" > ... </div>

<!-- Hide on medium and large devices --> 
<div class="hide-on-medium-and-up" > ... </div>

Responsive image

By default, all images are considered responsive and will adjust accordingly to the window size. In case you, for any sake, need a non responsive image, just add the class .no-responsive on it.

Class Detail Remarks
.no-responsive   Makes images non responsive
.circle   Makes a small circle image
.thumb   Makes a small square image 

<img src="..." alt="..." >
Circle image

Thumbnail

<!-- makes a circle image --> 
<img class="circle" src="..." alt="..." >

<!-- makes a square small image --> 
<img class="thumb" src="..." alt="..." >

Icons

We're using Ionic Icon Fonts as our set of icons. It's free and can be redistributed as well as Seed CSS.

Just to keep the flexibility, the icon set is not included on the Seed CSS stylesheet files. You should import it from an external source. If you would like to keep up to date to the latest versions from Ion icons, we strongly recommend you to get it from Ionic CDN.

In order to use those icons, add the following line to the HEAD tag of any page you're using Seed CSS: 

<!-- Without the protocol (http|https) means it will take in the same protocol as your page is -->
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" 
    href="//code.ionicframework.com/ionicons/2.0.1/css/ionicons.min.css">


… and many other. Check all >
or just go to: http://ionicons.com/
